title-group.article-title: Comparative studies on melt processable polyimides derived from 2,3,3′,4′-oxydiphthalic anhydride and 2,3,3′,4′-thioetherdiphthalic anhydride

article-meta.aff: Ningbo Key Laboratory of Polymer Materials, Ningbo Institute of Material Technology and Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Ningbo, Zhejiang, China

author-notes.corresp: Xingzhong Fang, Ningbo Key Laboratory of Polymer Materials, Ningbo Institute of Material Technology and Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Ningbo, Zhejiang, 315201, China. Email: fxzhong@nimte.ac.cn

abstract.p: Two thermoplastic polyimides were controllably synthesized with similar molecular weight from 2,3,3′,4′-oxydiphthalic anhydride (3,4′-ODPA) or 2,3,3′,4′-thioetherdiphthalic anhydride (3,4′-TDPA) with 4,4′-diaminodiphenyl ether (ODA) by a one-step method of m-cresol. The solubility and mechanical properties of these polymers were investigated for comparison. The thermal and melt processable properties of these polymers were examined carefully by differential scanning calorimetry, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), rheometer and melt index, and so on. It was found that the glass transition temperature (Tg) of 3,4′-TDPA/ODA was about 15°C lower than that of 3,4′-ODPA/ODA, the melt indices of 3,4′-TDPA/ODA at different temperatures were higher than those of 3,4′-ODPA/ODA, while the minimum melt viscosity of 3,4′-TDPA/ODA was lower than those of 3,4′-ODPA/ODA. Furthermore, TGA results showed that 3,4′-TDPA/ODA had different degradation mechanism in air compared with 3,4′-ODPA/ODA. The long-term thermooxidative stability results showed that 3,4′-TDPA/ODA had better thermal oxidative stability than 3,4′-ODPA/ODA at 410°C for 6 h in air, which could be associated with the results of apparent activation energy (Ea) of polymers calculated by TGA dynamics. The natural bond orbital charge of ethero atoms (S or O), and energy gap of the corresponding model compounds were also obtained by computational simulation to correlate with polymer properties.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Polyimides (PIs), as one type of high-temperature polymeric materials, due to their excellent thermal stability, superior mechanical properties and good chemical resistance, have been widely applied in many fields such as electronics, military and aerospace.1–6 However, most PIs are infusible and insoluble because of their rigid backbones and strong interchain interactions, limiting their processing and applications. Therefore, the study of melt processability has bloom into an interesting issue in the research of PIs. In order to improve their melt processablility, there have been numerous approaches reported in the literatures since the 1970s to develop the thermoplastic linear PIs, which focused on structural design and modification of dianhydride and diamine monomers, such as the introduction of flexible groups,7–10 the attachment of bulky lateral substitutions11–13 and the involvement of asymmetric moieties.14–17

Currently, the successful commercial thermoplastic PIs (TPIs), such as Ultem (General Electric Co., New York, USA) and Aurum (Mitsui Chemical Co., Tokyo, Japan), whose chemical structures are shown in Figure 1, possesses outstanding melt processability with higher thermal stability and lower melt viscosity. It was noted that the methods to improve the processability of these TPIs were focused on the new monomers with longer chain length and flexible linkages, which inevitably led to a decrease in glass transition temperature (Tg). Therefore, how to obtain the TPIs having better melt processability without sacrificing its heat resistance is a challenging work from both the academic and commercial perspectives.

caption.p: The chemical structures of Ultem and Aurum.

sec.p: Recently, Japanese researchers18–21 and Ding et al.22–27 have found that the isomeric PIs derived from isomeric dianhydrides showed higher Tg, lower melt viscosity and wide processing window, which provided a new insight to obtain the high-performance polymers with good processability and thermal stability. Therefore, it is possible to develop high-performance TPIs using isomeric PIs derived from dianhydride isomers.

Furthermore, the melt stability and thermal properties of TPIs are closely related to their chemical structures,28–30 so study on the structure–property relations of isomeric TPIs plays an important role for the development of new type TPIs. At present, 2,3,3′,4′-oxydiphthalic anhydride (3,4′-ODPA) and 2,3,3′,4′-thioetherdiphthalic anhydride (3,4′-TDPA) are the two most important common bridged isomeric dianhydrides that simultaneously introduce the asymmetric structure and the flexible moieties into main chain, making it possible to develop the high-performance TPIs.

In this article, two PIs with similar molecular weight derived from 3,4′-ODPA and 3,4′-TDPA were controllably synthesized by a one-step, high-temperature solution polycondensation method in m-cresol using phthalic anhydride (PA) as an end capper. The melt processability and thermal properties of PIs were comparatively investigated. In order to better understand the structure–property relations, the experimental and computational simulation data of corresponding model compounds were obtained to correlate with PI properties.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: PA was purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd (Shanghai, China). Ltd and 4,4′-diaminodiphenyl ether (ODA) was purchased from Shandong Wanda Chemical Co. Ltd (Dongying, China) and was purified by sublimation in vacuum before use. 3,4′-ODPA was purchased from Shanghai Research Institute of Synthetic Resins (Shanghai, China) and was recrystallized from a 1/1 volume ratio of acetic anhydride/toluene before use. All of the other reagents were from the Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd and were of analytical grade. 3,4′-TDPA was synthesized in our laboratory according to the literatures.31,32

sec.title: Measurements
sec.p: The inherent viscosities (ηinh) were determined at 30 ± 0.1°C with an Ubbelohde viscometer and the concentration was 0.5 g dL–1 in m-cresol. The Fourier-transform spectroscopy (FT-IR) spectra were obtained with a Thermo Nicolet 6700 FT-IR spectrometer, where the sample was prepared with potassium bromide (KBr) pellets. Proton nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker AV/ANCE at 400 MHz using deuterated chloroform (CDCl3) as a solvent and tetramethylsilane as an internal standard. Weight-average molecular weights (Mw) and number-average molecular weights were obtained via gel permeation chromatography on the basis of polymethylmethacrylate calibration on a Waters 2410 instrument with chloroform (CHCl3) as an eluent at a flow rate of 1.0 mL/min. The differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) was conducted on a Perkin-Elmer Diamond DSC system at a heating rate of 20°C/min under nitrogen (N2) atmosphere. The thermal stability of PIs was estimated using a Perkin-Elemer Diamond TG/DTA thermogravimetric analyzer at a heating rate of 10°C/min in N2 or an air atmosphere (flow rate of 50 mL/min) from 50°C to 800°C. The tensile measurements were carried out on an Instron model 5567 tensile tester at a crosshead speed of 5 mm/min at room temperature.

The rheological properties of PIs were performed on a rotational Physica MCR 301 rheometer in an air flow. The parallel plate diameter was 25 mm and the gap was set at about 1.0 mm in all the runs. Sample discs of 25 mm diameter and 1 mm thickness were prepared by press molding of the powder-like PI at 80°C under high pressure. The complex viscosity (η*) of PIs was measured by scanning the temperature from 280 to 450°C at a ramp rate of 5°C/min with a frequency of 1 Hz and a strain of 1%. Meanwhile, dynamic time sweep test was performed at 340°C to evaluate the melt stability of PIs. The η* data were isothermally collected at 340°C with a frequency of 1 Hz and a strain of 1%.

The melt flow property of PIs was performed on an SRZ 400E molten index instrument. Melt index (MI) was determined by melting a sample with maintaining at different temperatures for 2 min and measuring under a load of 12.5 kg.

The bond energy and natural bond orbital (NBO) charge were obtained by the quantum computation. All the calculations were carried out using the density functional theory (DFT) method in the Gaussian 09 package.33 The exchange correlation functional Becke, 3-parameter, Lee-Yang-Parr (B3LYP) was used. The B3LYP is carefully mixed with Hartree–Fock exchange calculated with Kohn–Sham orbits and the B88 exchange functional34 plus the LYP correlation functional.35 The all-electron basis set 6–31 g (d) was used to describe the C, N, O, S and H atoms.

sec.title: Synthesis of PIs
sec.p: The molecular weight controlled PI powders were synthesized by a one-step polycondensation with m-cresol as the solvent as shown in Figure 2. The typical synthetic procedure (take PI-2 as an example) was as follows: 4,4′-ODA (4.125 g, 20.6 mmol) and m-cresol (30 mL) were placed in a 100-mL two-necked flask fitted with a N2 inlet tube and a Dean-Stark trap topped by a condenser. The reaction flask was purged with dry N2, and the solution was heated to 100°C. The 3,4′-TDPA (6.526 g, 20 mmol) was not added until the complete dissolution of solids and reacted for 1 h. Then PA (0.1776 g, 1.2 mmol) and several drops of isoquinoline were added successively and the temperature of the oil bath was gradually raised to 195°C. The resulting homogeneous solution was stirred at these conditions for another 8 h under the steady flow of N2. After cooling to room temperature, the PI solution was diluted with m-cresol and slowly poured into a vigorously stirred solution of ethanol. The precipitate was filtered off, washed thoroughly with boiling ethanol and dried in vacuum at 100°C to afford PIs powder. FT-IR (KBr, cm−1): 1780, 1720 (C=O asymmetric and symmetric stretching); 1410 (C–S stretching); 1380 (C–N stretching); 725 (imide ring deformation). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3, δ, ppm): 8.04 (s, 1H), 7.99 (d, J = 7.7 Hz, 1H), 7.94 (d, J = 7.7 Hz, 1H), 7.83 (d, J = 7.4 Hz, 1H), 7.64 (d, J = 7.7 Hz, 1H), 7.43 (t, J = 8.0 Hz, 4H), 7.33 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H) and 7.19 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 4H).

caption.p: Synthesis of polyimides derived from 3,4′-ODPA and 3,4′-TDPA. 3,4′-ODPA: 2,3,3′,4′-oxydiphthalic anhydride; 3,4′-TDPA: 2,3,3′,4′-thioetherdiphthalic anhydride.

sec.p: PI-1 (3,4′-ODPA/ODA) powders were prepared by the similar method as described above. FT-IR (KBr, cm−1): 1780, 1720 (C=O asymmetric and symmetric stretching); 1255 (C–O stretching); 1380 (C–N stretching) and 725 (imide ring deformation).

The obtained PI powders were then dissolved in m-cresol at room temperature to afford about 15 wt% solution, which was cast onto glass substrates. Wet films were placed in an oven at 80°C for 12 h to release most of solvent. Then the films were gradually cured at 150°C for 0.5 h, 200°C for 0.5 h, 250°C for 0.5 h and finally 280°C for 0.5 h to form 20–30 μm thick PI films.

sec.title: Synthesis of model compounds
sec.p: The model compounds 1 and 2 were prepared according to previously reported methods31,32 as shown in Figure 3. The synthetic route of model compound 2 was as follows: 3,4′-TDPA (5 mmol), aniline (10 mmol), xylene (40 mL) and N,N-dimethylacetamide (10 mL) were placed in a 100-mL two-necked flask fitted with a N2 inlet tube and a Dean-Stark trap topped by a condenser. The reaction flask was purged with dry N2, and the solution was heated to 180°C for 8 h. After cooling to room temperature, the precipitate was filtered off, washed with ethanol and dried in vacuum at 120°C to afford powders of compound 2. Product was obtained with the yield of 86.5%, melting point (m.p.): 259°C, as determined by DSC (20°C/min). FT-IR (KBr, cm−1): 1780, 1722 (C=O asymmetric and symmetric stretching); 1410 (C–S stretching); 1380 (C–N stretching); 721 (imide ring deformation). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3, δ, ppm): 8.04 (s, 1H), 7.99 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.94 (dd, J1 = 7.6 Hz, J2 = 1.6 Hz, 1H), 7.83 (d, J = 7.2 Hz, 1H), 7.64 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.37–7.56 (m, 10H) and 7.33 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H).

caption.p: Synthesis of model compounds derived from 3,4′-ODPA and 3,4′-TDPA. 3,4′-ODPA: 2,3,3′,4′-oxydiphthalic anhydride; 3,4′-TDPA: 2,3,3′,4′-thioetherdiphthalic anhydride.

sec.p: Model compound 1 was prepared in an analogous procedure as model compound 2. Product was obtained with the yield of 92.5%, m.p.: 247°C, as determined by DSC (20°C/min). FT-IR (KBr, cm−1): 1778, 1720 (C=O asymmetric and symmetric stretching); 1250 (C–O stretching); 1380 (C–N stretching); 725 (imide ring deformation). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3, δ, ppm): 7.96 (d, J = 8.2 Hz, 1H), 7.87 (m, 2H) and 7.35–7.55 (m, 13H).

sec.title: Synthesis of PIs and model compounds
sec.p: PI-1 (3,4′-ODPA/ODA) and PI-2 (3,4′-TDPA/ODA) were prepared through a one-step, high-temperature solution polymerization method with m-cresol as the solvent and isoquinoline as the catalyst at 195°C for 8 h (Figure 2). PA was used as the end-capping agent to terminate the reactive amine end group of polymer and the molecular weights were controlled by the adjustment of the offsets of anhydride to ODA. The results of ηinh and molecular weight of PIs were summarized in Table 1. The chemical structures of PIs were confirmed with FT-IR and 1H NMR spectroscopy. These PIs exhibit characteristic imide group absorptions around 1780 cm−1 (asymmetrical C=O stretching), 1720 cm−1 (symmetrical C=O stretching), 1380 cm−1 (C–N stretching) and 725 cm−1 (imide ring deformation) in FT-IR spectra. Figure 4 shows 1H NMR spectrum of a representative PI (PI-2) in CDCl3, and all the signals have been assigned to the hydrogen atoms of the repeating unit. It was noted that the two PIs with controlled molecular weight were successfully obtained.

caption.p: 1H NMR spectrum of PI-2 in CDCl3. 1H NMR: proton nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy; CDCl3: deuterated chloroform.
Inherent viscosities and molecular weight distribution of PIs.

fn.p: PIs: polyimides; ηinh: inherent viscosities; Mn: number-average molecular weights; Mw: weight-average molecular weight.
aMeasured at a concentration of 0.5 g/dL in m-cresol at 30°C.

sec.p: As shown in Figure 3, the corresponding model compounds were synthesized by the reaction of dianhydride with aniline in the presence of xylene as the azeotropic agent and dimethylacetamide (DMAc) as the solvent at 180°C for 8 h. The structures of model compounds were confirmed by 1H NMR and FT-IR spectra. As shown in Figure 5, all the hydrogen of a representative model compound (2) have been completely assigned to the 1H NMR spectrum. Furthermore, the characteristic absorption peaks of FT-IR spectra around 1780 cm−1 (asymmetrical C=O stretching), 1720 cm−1 (symmetrical C=O stretching), 1380 cm−1 (C–N stretching) and 725 cm−1 (imide ring deformation) were assigned to the imide groups, demonstrating that the target structure of model compounds have been successfully obtained.

caption.p: 1H NMR spectrum of model compound 2 in CDCl3. 1H NMR: proton nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy; CDCl3: deuterated chloroform.

sec.title: Solubility of PIs
sec.p: Solubility is a major indicator for the intermolecular interaction, chain flexibility and conformation of PIs.6 It was noted that 3,3′- or 3,4′-based on PIs were generally more soluble than the corresponding 4,4′-based on PIs because of the irregular chain structures resulted from the isomeric effect.22–25 The solubility of two PIs was investigated qualitatively in various solvents, and the results were summarized in Table 2. We found that the two PIs had excellent solubility in aprotic polar solvents, such as m-cresol, CHCl3, N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP), DMAc, N,N-dimethyl formamide, 1,1,2,2-tetrachloroethane and p-chlorophenol at room temperature, and PI-2 was soluble in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) and γ-butyrolactone on heating condition. The good solubility of these polymers could be attributed to the introduction of the flexible linkages (–O–, –S–) into the polymer main chain, and the irregular chain structure of 3,4′-isomers, which decreased the interchain interactions and hindered denser chain stacking.22–25

caption.p: Solubility of PIs.a

fn.p: PIs: polyimides.
Key: ++: soluble at room temperature; +−: soluble on heating and −: insoluble.

a Qualitative solubility was determined at 2% w/v concentration, stirring for 24 h at room temperature or heating up to the solvents boiling temperature for those samples remained insoluble at room temperature.

bCHCl3: chloroform; DMF: N,N-dimethyl formamide; DMAc: dimethylacetamide; NMP: N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone; DMSO: dimethyl sulfoxide; TCE: 1,1,2,2-tetrachloroethane; p-CPhol: p-chlorophenol; GBL: γ-butyrolactone.

sec.title: Thermal properties of PIs
sec.p: The thermal behavior of two PIs was evaluated by the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and DSC, and the results were listed in Table 3. Tg depends on the movement of polymer molecular chain segment. As shown in Table 3, the Tg value of PI-1 was about 15°C higher than that of PI-2. Higher Tg value of PI-1 could be caused by more difficult chain rotation of polymers, which could be due to the more flexible C–S–C than C–O–C bonds in the polymeric chain resulted from the lower electronegativity of sulfur atom.36

caption.p: Thermal and mechanical properties of PIs.

fn.p: PIs: polyimides; Tg: glass transition temperature; T5%: temperatures of 5% weight loss; TGA: thermogravimetric analysis; DSC: differential scanning calorimetry.
a Obtained by DSC at a heating rate of 20°C/min in N2.
b Temperature at 5% weight loss were recorded by TGA at a heating rate of 10°C/min.
c Residual weight (%) at 800°C in N2.

sec.p: The thermal stability and thermooxidative stability of PIs were studied by TGA. As shown in Figure 6 and Table 3, the temperatures of 5% weight loss (T5%) in N2 and air atmospheres of these PIs stayed in the range of 532–537°C and 525–531°C, respectively, demonstrating that the PIs possessed a high and similar thermal stability and thermooxidative stability. Furthermore, the excellent heat resistance quality of the PIs could also be testified by the high char yield showing over 55% at 800°C in N2. Interestingly, we found that the two polymers have the similar degradation curves in N2 atmosphere as shown in Figure 6(a). However, it is worthwhile to note that the process of TGA decomposition plot of PI-2 in air is different from that of PI-1. As shown in Figure 6(b), the degradation of PI-2 is divided into two stages while the degradation of PI-1 has only one degradation stage. This may be ascribed to the different degradation mechanisms for sulfur-containing PI-2. The first stage is the reaction process of sulfur and air and the second stage is the decomposition of the backbone of PIs.37

caption.p: TGA and derivative thermogravimetric curves of PIs at a heating rate of 10°C/min in (a) N2 and (b) air. TGA: thermogravimetric analysis; PIs: polyimides.

sec.p: In order to further investigate the thermal stability of two PIs, the long-term thermal stability of PI-1 was compared with that of PI-2. Figure 7 displayed the isothermal weight loss curve of PIs at 410°C for 6 h in air. The weight loss occurred very slowly for PI-2 while the weight of PI-1 decreased much faster, revealing that PI-2 had a much higher thermooxidative stability than PI-129 (Figures 8 to 11).

caption.p: Isothermal weight loss curves of PI-1 and PI-2 at 410°C in air.
TGA curves of PI-1 for 6 h at different temperatures in air. TGA: thermogravimetric analysis.
Plot of ln (time to fixed conversion) versus 1/T at the several degrees of conversion from data presented in Figure 8.
TGA curves of PI-2 for 6 h at different temperatures in air. TGA: thermogravimetric analysis.
Plot of ln (time to fixed conversion) versus 1/T at the several degrees of conversion from data presented in Figure 10.

sec.p: Generally, the apparent activation energy (Ea) is used in quantifying the thermal stability and thermooxidative stability of polymers, and higher Ea indicates that bond breakage decomposition requires higher temperatures.38 In order to verify the difference in the thermal stability of two PIs, their Ea values were calculated by the MacCallum method,39 which was extensively used to determine the kinetic parameters by isothermal degradation experiments. The method was based on the following linear equation: lnt=a+b∗1/Tiso, where t is the time needed to reach a fixed degree of degradation D, Tiso is the temperature of isothermal experiment, b = Ea/R and R is the gas constant. The Ea values at various degrees of degradation can then be obtained by the slope of the linear relationships ln t versus 1/Tiso.

According to the MacCallum method, isothermal degradation experiments of PI-1 and PI-2 in air at 410°C, 430°C and 450°C were conducted, respectively. The experimental data were treated to determine the Ea values for the degrees of degradation D = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6%. Based on the above method, the Ea values of degradation in air for PI-1 and PI-2 were reported in Tables 4 and 5, respectively. It was found that PI-2 has higher Ea value of about 180 kJ/mol than PI-1 of about 90 kJ/mol, thus manifesting that PI-2 had a much higher thermooxidative stability. Note that the thermal stability result obtained by MacCallum method is consistent with the result of the long-term thermal stability experimental.

caption.p: Regression coefficients and Ea by MacCallum equations for the isothermal degradation in air of PI-2 at several degrees of conversion.

fn.p: a a is intercept of the linear relationships ln t versus 1/Tiso.
b b = Ea/R.
Ea: activation energy.

caption.p: Regression coefficients and Ea by MacCallum equations for the isothermal degradation in air of PI-1 at several degrees of conversion.

fn.p: a a is intercept of the linear relationships ln t versus 1/Tiso.
b b = Ea/R.
Ea: activation energy.

sec.title: Melt processability
sec.p: Rheology behavior of the two PI powders having similar Mw of about 33,000 g/mol and ηinh of about 0.44 dL/g was investigated. As seen from Figure 12(a), η* of PIs dramatically decreased with an increase in temperature. It was interesting to note that the minimum η* of PI-2 was as low as 100 Pa·s at about 400°C, which was about an order of magnitude lower than that of PI-1. In addition, as shown in Table 6, the MIs at different temperatures of PI-1 were lower than those of the corresponding PI-2, indicating that PI-2 has lower melt viscosity and much better melt processability than PI-1. The results might be related to the lower Tg of PI-2 than that of PI-1 because of the lower electronegativity of sulfur atom with respect to the oxygen one, giving rise to more flexible C–S–C than C–O–C bonds in the polymeric chain and therefore to weaker interchain interactions of polymers.36

caption.p: (a) Melt complex viscosities of PI-1 and PI-2 as a function of temperature (the ηinh of PI-1 and PI-2 were 0.44 and 0.45 dL/g, respectively) and (b) melt complex viscosities of PI-1 and PI-2 as a function of time in air at 340°C. ηinh: inherent viscosities.
Rheology properties and melt index of PIs.

tr.th: Melt viscosity variation at 340°C for 1 h (Pa·s)

fn.p: PIs: polyimides; MVR: melt viscosity ratio; MI: melt index.
a Measured at a load of 12.5 kg.

sec.p: In addition, the melt stabilization of PIs was also characterized by the isothermal viscosity sweeps. As shown in Table 6, the melt viscosities at 340°C for 1 h increased from 6940 to 10,300 Pa·s for PI-1, and from 2590 to 3470 Pa·s for PI-2. The melt viscosity ratio (MVR) calculated by the equation (MVR = MV30/MV5), where MV5 and MV30 are the melt viscosities (Pa·s) measured at 5 and 30 min after the solid sample was completely molten, respectively, was usually employed to describe the melt stability.40 Furthermore, the polymer could be considered as having good melt stability if its MVR value was located in the range of 1.0–1.5. From Table 6, PI-I (MVR = 1.25) and PI-2 (MVR = 1.13) showed good melt stabilities. Moreover, the MVR data of PI-2 was lower than that of PI-1, implying that PI-2 showed better melt stability than PI-1 (Figure 12(b)).

sec.title: Model compounds studies
sec.p: Due to the similar performance of PIs and the corresponding model compounds, the thermal properties of model compounds could predict the performance of PIs to a certain extent. In order to correlate with the polymer properties, two corresponding model compounds were prepared in our laboratory. The melt temperature, T5%, maximum mass loss rate temperature and char yield of them, as measured by DSC and TGA, were listed in Table 7. From the TGA measurements (Table 7 and Figure 13), the T5% value and the char yield at 800°C of compound 2 in N2 were 386°C and 11.2%, while those of compound 1 were 363°C and 3.95%, respectively, indicating that compound 2 had a better thermal stability than compound 1.

caption.p: TGA curves for model compounds 1 and 2 at a heating rate of 10°C/min under N2. TGA: thermogravimetric analysis.
Thermal properties and computational simulation dataa of model compounds.

fn.p: Tm: melt temperature; T5%: temperatures of 5% weight loss; Tmax: maximum mass loss rate temperature; NBO: natural bond orbital; Δ∊: energy gap; DFT: density functional theory; DSC: differential scanning calorimetry; TGA: thermogravimetric analysis.
a Calculated by the DFT method in the Gaussian 09 package.
b Obtained by DSC at a heating rate of 20°C/min in N2.
c Temperature at 5% weight loss were recorded by TGA at a heating rate of 10°C/min.
d Maximum mass loss rate temperature were recorded by derivative thermogravimetric curve.
e Residual weight (%) at 800°C in N2.

sec.p: Table 7 illustrated the NBO charges of ethero atoms (S or O) and the energy gaps (Δ∊) of model compound, calculated by the DFT method in the Gaussian 09 package. As shown in Table 7, the more NBO charge of sulfur atom with respect to the oxygen one, gave rise to the better thermal stability, because electron-deficient compounds were commonly preferable for polymer thermooxidative stability,28 and model compound 2 had smaller Δ∊ value of 0.137 than model compound 1 of 0.145, which should cause the stronger charge transition, thus improving the thermal stability.41

Based on the experimental and computational simulation results of model compounds, it was quite reasonable that PI-2 had an outstanding thermal and thermooxidative stability and the superior thermal stability of PI-2 could be associated with the more NBO charge of sulfur atom and the smaller Δ∊ of model compound 2.

sec.title: Mechanical properties
sec.p: The mechanical properties of two PI films were also listed in Table 3. The PIs exhibited good mechanical properties with tensile strengths of about 90–98 MPa, elongation at break of about 6–7%, and Young’s modulus of about 2.6–2.9 GPa, showing a promising potential for the application of engineering plastics. It was noted that the structural changes of the two PIs have no apparent effect on mechanical properties.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Two thermoplastic PIs with similar molecular weight from 3,4′-ODPA and 3,4′-TDPA with ODA were successfully prepared by a one-step, high-temperature solution polycondensation method in the presence of PA as the end-capping agent. The two polymers have good solubility in common aprotic polar solvents because of the introduction of the flexible linkages (–O–, –S–) and the irregular chain structure of 3,4′-isomers into the polymer main chain. It was found that the sulfur-containing PI-2 had two degradation stages, while PI-1 had only one degradation stage in air. The long-term thermooxidative stability of PI-2 at 410°C in air was better than that of PI-1, which could be explained by the higher Ea of PI-2 obtained by MacCallum method, and the more NBO charge of sulfur atom and the smaller Δ∊ of model compound 2 obtained by computational simulation results of model compounds. The effect of substitution of ether oxygen atoms with sulfur ones of these polymers was found to be a lowering in the Tg value and minimum melt viscosity, an increase in the MI. The results were explained as due to the presence of more flexible C–S–C than C–O–C bonds in the polymeric chain. Because of the excellent thermal stability and melt processability of PI-2, it could be expected that PI-2 would have a more promising potential for future applications of engineering plastics than PI-1.
